text:
Two people have influenced my choice of undergraduate and graduate studies. The first one was my older brother. Ever since I was a child, I struggled to comprehend my brother's interest in physics: he was in awe of it.And Whenever I inquired about it, he would always respond that I would understand when I advanced in my studies. So I began my journey: I had to understand his fascination, and I guess, in fine,I wanted to understand him better, to "get him". Before I knew it, physics had become my favorite subject and I had followed his footsteps to undertake an undergraduate degree in Electrical engineering.If you're wondering,I liked what I was doing, even found it quite fascinating, but despite my earnest efforts I couldn't quite grasp what my brother had been "seeing" all along in this field of science. I also felt whatever studies I pursued had  to have a little bit of "me ", my "color" in it.That's when I came across a TED talk presented by one of the first man,in Paris, to bring medecine and programming together. He talked about how his most cherished desire was to become a doctor but after failing twice his "medical qualifications" exam, he  looked towards his hobby, programming, to draw up his career path. After his studies, he was approached by a professor who offered to put his programming skills at the service of medecine.He then realised through his journey, what his dream had really been about: not to become a doctor but to save lives.And he was able to do just that.The speech he gave, with tears in his eyes, resonated with me. That came at a moment I was facing a dilemma so I decided that it was a worthwhile purpose to pursue, to try and realise and began my studies in Biomedical Engineering.
I still wonder though,sometimes, when I look into my brother's eyes what I could possibly have missed, what secret I couldn't unlock...
